1.11: The flowers appear on the earth; The time of singing is come, And the voice of the turtle is heard in our land;
1.10: For, lo, the winter is past, The rain is over and gone;
1.13: O my dove, that art in the clefts of the rock, in the covert of the cliff, Let me see thy countenance, let me hear thy voice; For sweet is thy voice, and thy countenance is comely.’
1.12: The fig-tree putteth forth her green figs, And the vines in blossom give forth their fragrance. Arise, my love, my fair one, and come away.
1.15: My beloved is mine, and I am his, That feedeth among the lilies.
1.14: ’Take us the foxes, the little foxes, that spoil the vineyards; For our vineyards are in blossom.’
1.16: Until the day breathe, and the shadows flee away, Turn, my beloved, and be thou like a gazelle or a young hart Upon the mountains of spices.
1.1: As a lily among thorns, So is my love among the daughters.
1.0: I am a rose of Sharon, A lily of the valleys.
1.3: He hath brought me to the banqueting-house, And his banner over me is love.
1.2: As an apple-tree among the trees of the wood, So is my beloved among the sons. Under its shadow I delighted to sit, And its fruit was sweet to my taste.
1.5: Let his left hand be under my head, And his right hand embrace me.
1.4: ’Stay ye me with dainties, refresh me with apples; For I am love-sick.’
1.7: Hark! my beloved! behold, he cometh, Leaping upon the mountains, skipping upon the hills.
1.6: ’I adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem, By the gazelles, and by the hinds of the field, That ye awaken not, nor stir up love, until it please.’
1.9: My beloved spoke, and said unto me: ‘Rise up, my love, my fair one, and come away.
1.8: My beloved is like a gazelle or a young hart; Behold, he standeth behind our wall, He looketh in through the windows, He peereth through the lattice.

0.11: While the king sat at his table, My spikenard sent forth its fragrance.
0.10: We will make thee circlets of gold With studs of silver.
0.13: My beloved is unto me as a cluster of henna In the vineyards of En-gedi.
0.12: My beloved is unto me as a bag of myrrh, That lieth betwixt my breasts.
0.15: Behold, thou art fair, my beloved, yea, pleasant; Also our couch is leafy.
0.14: Behold, thou art fair, my love; behold, thou art fair; Thine eyes are as doves. .
0.16: The beams of our houses are cedars, And our panels are cypresses.
0.1: Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth— For thy love is better than wine.
0.0: THE song of songs, which is Solomon’s.
0.3: Draw me, we will run after thee; The king hath brought me into his chambers; We will be glad and rejoice in thee, We will find thy love more fragrant than wine! Sincerely do they love thee.
0.2: Thine ointments have a goodly fragrance; Thy name is as ointment poured forth; Therefore do the maidens love thee.
0.5: Look not upon me, that I am swarthy, That the sun hath tanned me; My mother’s sons were incensed against me, They made me keeper of the vineyards; But mine own vineyard have I not kept.’
0.4: ’I am black, but comely, O ye daughters of Jerusalem, As the tents of Kedar, As the curtains of Solomon.
0.7: If thou know not, O thou fairest among women, Go thy way forth by the footsteps of the flock And feed thy kids, beside the shepherds’tents.
0.6: Tell me, O thou whom my soul loveth, Where thou feedest, where thou makest thy flock to rest at noon; For why should I be as one that veileth herself Beside the flocks of thy companions?
0.9: Thy cheeks are comely with circlets, Thy neck with beads.
0.8: I have compared thee, O my love, To a steed in Pharaoh’s chariots.

3.11: A garden shut up is my sister, my bride; A spring shut up, a fountain sealed.
3.10: Thy lips, O my bride, drop honey— Honey and milk are under thy tongue; And the smell of thy garments is like the smell of Lebanon.
3.13: Spikenard and saffron, calamus and cinnamon, With all trees of frankincense; Myrrh and aloes, with all the chief spices.
3.12: Thy shoots are a park of pomegranates, With precious fruits; Henna with spikenard plants,
3.15: Awake, O north wind; And come, thou south; Blow upon my garden, That the spices thereof may flow out. Let my beloved come into his garden, And eat his precious fruits.
3.14: Thou art a fountain of gardens, A well of living waters, And flowing streams from Lebanon.
3.1: Thy teeth are like a flock of ewes all shaped alike, Which are come up from the washing; Whereof all are paired, and none faileth among them.
3.0: Behold, thou art fair, my love; behold, thou art fair; Thine eyes are as doves behind thy veil; Thy hair is as a flock of goats, that trail down from mount Gilead.
3.3: Thy neck is like the tower of David Builded with turrets, Whereon there hang a thousand shields, All the armour of the mighty men.
3.2: Thy lips are like a thread of scarlet, And thy mouth is comely; Thy temples are like a pomegranate split open Behind thy veil.
3.5: Until the day breathe, And the shadows flee away, I will get me to the mountain of myrrh, And to the hill of frankincense.
3.4: Thy two breasts are like two fawns That are twins of a gazelle, Which feed among the lilies.
3.7: Come with me from Lebanon, my bride, With me from Lebanon; Look from the top of Amana, From the top of Senir and Hermon, From the lions’dens, From the mountains of the leopards.
3.6: Thou art all fair, my love; And there is no spot in thee.
3.9: How fair is thy love, my sister, my bride! How much better is thy love than wine! And the smell of thine ointments than all manner of spices!
3.8: Thou hast ravished my heart, my sister, my bride; Thou hast ravished my heart with one of thine eyes, With one bead of thy necklace.

2.10: Go forth, O ye daughters of Zion, And gaze upon king Solomon, Even upon the crown wherewith his mother hath crowned him in the day of his espousals, And in the day of the gladness of his heart.
2.1: ’I will rise now, and go about the city, In the streets and in the broad ways, I will seek him whom my soul loveth.’ I sought him, but I found him not.
2.0: By night on my bed I sought him whom my soul loveth; I sought him, but I found him not.
2.3: Scarce had I passed from them, When I found him whom my soul loveth: I held him, and would not let him go, Until I had brought him into my mother’s house, And into the chamber of her that conceived me.
2.2: The watchmen that go about the city found me: ‘Saw ye him whom my soul loveth?’
2.5: Who is this that cometh up out of the wilderness Like pillars of smoke, Perfumed with myrrh and frankincense, With all powders of the merchant?
2.4: ’I adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem, By the gazelles, and by the hinds of the field, That ye awaken not, nor stir up love, Until it please.’
2.7: They all handle the sword, And are expert in war; Every man hath his sword upon his thigh, Because of dread in the night.
2.6: Behold, it is the litter of Solomon; Threescore mighty men are about it, Of the mighty men of Israel.
2.9: He made the pillars thereof of silver, The top thereof of gold, The seat of it of purple, The inside thereof being inlaid with love, From the daughters of Jerusalem.
2.8: King Solomon made himself a palanquin Of the wood of Lebanon.

5.11: Before I was aware, my soul set me Upon the chariots of my princely people.
5.10: I went down into the garden of nuts, To look at the green plants of the valley, To see whether the vine budded, And the pomegranates were in flower.
5.1: ’My beloved is gone down into his garden, To the beds of spices, To feed in the gardens, And to gather lilies.
5.0: ’Whither is thy beloved gone, O thou fairest among women? Whither hath thy beloved turned him, That we may seek him with thee?’
5.3: Thou art beautiful, O my love, as Tirzah, Comely as Jerusalem, Terrible as an army with banners.
5.2: I am my beloved’s, and my beloved is mine, That feedeth among the lilies.’
5.5: Thy teeth are like a flock of ewes, Which are come up from the washing; Whereof all are paired, And none faileth among them.
5.4: Turn away thine eyes from me, For they have overcome me. Thy hair is as a flock of goats, That trail down from Gilead.
5.7: There are threescore queens, And fourscore concubines, And maidens without number.
5.6: Thy temples are like a pomegranate split open Behind thy veil.
5.9: Who is she that looketh forth as the dawn, Fair as the moon, Clear as the sun, Terrible as an army with banners?
5.8: My dove, my undefiled, is but one; She is the only one of her mother; She is the choice one of her that bore her. The daughters saw her, and called her happy; Yea, the queens and the concubines, and they praised her.

4.11: His eyes are like doves Beside the water-brooks; Washed with milk, And fitly set.
4.10: His head is as the most fine gold, His locks are curled, And black as a raven.
4.13: His hands are as rods of gold Set with beryl; His body is as polished ivory Overlaid with sapphires.
4.12: His cheeks are as a bed of spices, As banks of sweet herbs; His lips are as lilies, Dropping with flowing myrrh.
4.15: His mouth is most sweet; Yea, he is altogether lovely. This is my beloved, and this is my friend, O daughters of Jerusalem.’
4.14: His legs are as pillars of marble, Set upon sockets of fine gold; His aspect is like Lebanon, Excellent as the cedars.
4.1: I sleep, but my heart waketh; Hark! my beloved knocketh: ‘Open to me, my sister, my love, my dove, my undefiled; For my head is filled with dew, My locks with the drops of the night.’
4.0: I am come into my garden, my sister, my bride; I have gathered my myrrh with my spice; I have eaten my honeycomb with my honey; I have drunk my wine with my milk. Eat, O friends; Drink, yea, drink abundantly, O beloved.
4.3: My beloved put in his hand by the hole of the door, And my heart was moved for him.
4.2: I have put off my coat; How shall I put it on? I have washed my feet; How shall I defile them?
4.5: I opened to my beloved; But my beloved had turned away, and was gone. My soul failed me when he spoke. I sought him, but I could not find him; I called him, but he gave me no answer.
4.4: I rose up to open to my beloved; And my hands dropped with myrrh, And my fingers with flowing myrrh, Upon the handles of the bar.
4.7: ’I adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem, If ye find my beloved, what will ye tell him? That I am love-sick.’
4.6: The watchmen that go about the city found me, They smote me, they wounded me; The keepers of the walls took away my mantle from me.
4.9: ’My beloved is white and ruddy, Pre-eminent above ten thousand.
4.8: ’What is thy beloved more than another beloved, O thou fairest among women? What is thy beloved more than another beloved, That thou dost so adjure us?’

7.11: My vineyard, which is mine, is before me; Thou, O Solomon, shalt have the thousand, And those that keep the fruit thereof two hundred.
7.10: Solomon had a vineyard at Baal-hamon; He gave over the vineyard unto keepers; Every one for the fruit thereof Brought in a thousand pieces of silver.
7.13: Make haste, my beloved, And be thou like to a gazelle or to a young hart Upon the mountains of spices.
7.12: Thou that dwellest in the gardens, The companions hearken for thy voice: ‘Cause me to hear it.’
7.1: I would lead thee, and bring thee into my mother’s house, That thou mightest instruct me; I would cause thee to drink of spiced wine, Of the juice of my pomegranate.
7.0: Oh that thou wert as my brother, That sucked the breasts of my mother! When I should find thee without, I would kiss thee; Yea, and none would despise me.
7.3: ’I adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem: Why should ye awaken, or stir up love, Until it please?’
7.2: His left hand should be under my head, And his right hand should embrace me.
7.5: Set me as a seal upon thy heart, As a seal upon thine arm; For love is strong as death, Jealousy is cruel as the grave; The flashes thereof are flashes of fire, A very flame of the LORD.
7.4: Who is this that cometh up from the wilderness, Leaning upon her beloved? Under the apple-tree I awakened thee; There thy mother was in travail with thee; There was she in travail and brought thee forth.
7.7: We have a little sister, And she hath no breasts; What shall we do for our sister In the day when she shall be spoken for?
7.6: Many waters cannot quench love, Neither can the floods drown it; If a man would give all the substance of his house for love, He would utterly be contemned.
7.9: I am a wall, And my breasts like the towers thereof; Then was I in his eyes As one that found peace.
7.8: If she be a wall, We will build upon her a turret of silver; And if she be a door, We will enclose her with boards of cedar.

6.11: Come, my beloved, let us go forth into the field; let us lodge in the villages.
6.10: I am my beloved’s, and his desire is toward me.
6.13: The mandrakes give forth fragrance, and at our doors are all manner of precious fruits, new and old, which I have laid up for thee, O my beloved.
6.12: Let us get up early to the vineyards; let us see whether the vine hath budded, whether the vine-blossom be opened, and the pomegranates be in flower; there will I give thee my love.
6.1: How beautiful are thy steps in sandals, O prince’s daughter! The roundings of thy thighs are like the links of a chain, The work of the hands of a skilled workman.
6.0: Return, return, O Shulammite; Return, return, that we may look upon thee. What will ye see in the Shulammite? As it were a dance of two companies.
6.3: Thy two breasts are like two fawns that are twins of a gazelle.
6.2: Thy navel is like a round goblet, wherein no mingled wine is wanting; Thy belly is like a heap of wheat Set about with lilies.
6.5: Thy head upon thee is like Carmel, and the hair of thy head like purple; The king is held captive in the tresses thereof.
6.4: Thy neck is as a tower of ivory; Thine eyes as the pools in Heshbon, By the gate of Bath-rabbim; Thy nose is like the tower of Lebanon Which looketh toward Damascus.
6.7: This thy stature is like to a palm-tree, and thy breasts to clusters of grapes.
6.6: How fair and how pleasant art thou, O love, for delights! .
6.9: And the roof of thy mouth like the best wine, That glideth down smoothly for my beloved, moving gently the lips of those that are asleep.’
6.8: I said: ‘I will climb up into the palm-tree, I will take hold of the branches thereof; and let thy breasts be as clusters of the vine, And the smell of thy countenance like apples;
